intro: Bassia longistyla, commonly known as the long-styled bassia, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the western United States. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces tiny, greenish-white flowers that are typically inconspicuous, with the male and female reproductive structures positioned on separate branches. Its leaves are usually narrow and fleshy, adapted to conserve water in its harsh environment. Bassia longistyla is often found in disturbed soils and is sometimes considered an invasive species in certain areas.
